snippet.textDisplay:
Looking through the comments it seems that a number of people think this video is in some way bias towards a specific ideology.

If the system were to change to PR then smaller parties from both sides of the aisle would benefit - the Brexit Party, the Lib Dems and the Greens would all pick up a significant number of additional seats.

In fact as we mentioned towards then end of the video parties across the political divide are calling for changes. In fact the Brexit Party's manfiesto contains some of the most radical constitutional changes.

Essentially my point is that highlighting the way the electoral system works isn't bias towards either side. Parties from both sides would benefit. Parties from both sides advocated for it.

You're more than welcome to disagree with PR, but to say that it's only being suggested because Labour lost is untrue. The Brexit Party have more to gain from PR than Labour do and that's why their manifesto is full of constitutional changes.

snippet.textDisplay: The reason the current system better represents the will of the electorate and is better in general than what you are proposing is because it better represents changes in the electorate (which reflect the grievances caused by new issues such as brexit or whatever). A /very/ small change in the electorate can completely change who is MP which gives more power to the people who join pressure groups and actually attempt to speak to their local MPs, since they'll be in fear of losing their seat. You've posted a lot of videos about how the current system is a poor representation but you clearly don't take into account why this system has been consistent for so long and how it manages to correct the mistakes that government routinely makes through the electorate's decisions.

snippet.textDisplay:
I am British, but live in South America. I moved here 15 years just when the left party was taking power. They have proportional voting here. The winner has to get a majority of the votes.

What happened recently was in the first round, the LEFT won the vote. Under the UK system, they would have taken power. HOWEVER they did not win a majority. So the two leading parties are put forward for a second election.

UTIMATELY the right won the election because all those that didn't vote for the right or left the first time round voted for the right the second time round, so the left lost after 15 years in power.

You can't have it every way.

snippet.textDisplay: NZ uses MMP, we have 2 votes, one for our local MP, which uses FPTP, and one party vote. If an MP wins their local seat they get in and the remaining seats are split according to the party vote with MPs selected from a preferential list. This forces compromise and coalition deals, with our current government consisting of a coalition of Labour & NZ First, with confidence and supply from the Greens. Although these parties all got less votes than National, the sum of their votes is greater, meaning together they represent a majority of voters. Our system could do with a little tweaking but overall is a great system.
snippet.textOriginal: NZ uses MMP, we have 2 votes, one for our local MP, which uses FPTP, and one party vote. Although these parties all got less votes than National, the sum of their votes is greater, meaning together they represent a majority of voters. Our system could do with a little tweaking but overall is a great system.

snippet.textDisplay:
I should start by telling you I'm from the United States and, as you're probably aware, we do not have a Parliamentary system. So you can certainly take that into account when evaluating my opinion. That said, here is my opinion (for what it's worth).
While on the surface it may seem fair to have a "proportional electoral system" as described in this video, it's important to note that one of the effects of such a system is the "nationalizing" of election results, i.e. people outside of your local area of representation get some say in who gets elected to represent you. The left in the United States uses this argument against the system we use to elect our President, the "electoral college." The downside of nationalizing elections in this way is that populated urban centers (which necessarily have a different sub-culture than rural areas) end up effectively usurping rural representation and forcing their views on people they do not understand and who will ultimately view this as "foreign" intervention in their local affairs. The reason this is an important consideration is that this is a situation that tends to cause people to "split from the group," e.g. Brexit, Scottish independence, or State secession in the U.S. People (down to a very local level) need to feel they have their own voice in order to feel "fairly" represented and to help prevent a larger-scale (national) majority from running roughshod over the minority.

snippet.textDisplay:
We have a different system in 🇩🇪 Germany, which in my opinion is more democratic than the British system. Here are the key facts:

If we elect our Parliament (Bundestag), we have two votes. Half of Parliament is made up of members elected directly (Erststimme; first vote) and the other half of parliamentarians elected via party lists (Zweitstimme; second vote).
We give the first vote to the candidates in whose constituency we live. The candidates who get the most votes in their constituency are elected to Parliament. The first vote is therefore roughly the same as the British electoral system.
But the second vote is the more important one. It counts nationwide and determines the distribution of seats in parliament. A party must receive at least 5% of the second votes in order to be allowed to enter parliament.

To illustrate this: Assuming the parliament would have 100 seats and a party would have 10 direct candidates by the first vote, but receive 15% of the second votes. This party would therefore be represented in parliament with 15 seats and not just 10.
If, on the other hand, a party has received 10 direct candidates but only 8% or just 4% of the second votes, the party still retains the 10 seats. The seats of the direct candidates are safe in each case. It does not matter whether the party received the 5% or not.

The second example also shows that the total number of seats in parliament is not fixed. The described situation would lead to additional seats being filled by party lists candidates, so that the distribution of seats would correspond to the second vote.
At the moment, our Parliament has more seats than ever before (709 instead of 598), which is causing massive additional costs. That is why all parties except the ruling conservative Christian Democrats want to supplement an upper limit on the number of seats in Parliament in our electoral system.

snippet.textDisplay:
We have MMP in NZ and it's a far far far better system. Everyone's vote counts. Yes, you end up with coalition governments more often, but that's what happens when the govt needs to command support from 51% of the people.

That being said, MMP is not a perfect system. Under MMP, we've tended to:
- Wipe out small parties after they've been part of a coalition
- allow centrist parties to have disproportionate power as kingmakers
- lead to perverse incentives and dodgy deals if you have a 'coat-tail' threshhold (it's complicated to explain)

But it's still a better system than FPP, which can have the top two problems, as well as much much worse ones.

snippet.textDisplay:
One thing this perspective doesn't appreciate is how these results actually dovetail with other voting system, just at a different level.


Take something like instant runoff voting. With IRV you have succeeding rounds of dropping the weakest candidate on a per-ballot basis. Well, the results TLDR News is putting on the screen are doing the same thing, dropping the weakest parties. It serves the same function, just in a more structured way.


TLDR News says these results don't reflect the public, but that's not quite right. They DO reflect the public, just measured a bit differently from ways TLDR would prefer. The different ways of measuring have different advantages, but they're still legitimate and reflect different preferences of the viewer. Different biases, I might even say :)


The first past the post results have the advantage of dropping weak parties and poorly supported perspectives early in the process so that small minorities of people don't have outsized influence in the Parliament. Whether that advantage is greater or worse than the philosophical disadvantages is in the eye of the beholder.

snippet.textDisplay:
I can totally see how the proportional system would give more voices and to some extent I favour that, but seeing what is happening in other countries I'm not sure the system is any better. The need to form coalitions to avoid a hung parliament makes for very unpleasant political outcomes. It is exactly how Italy eventually found itself giving up to a nightmareish comeback of fascist ideologies, for example. And it would have made the DUP a real force with May's government (and maybe that's why we see more flat Earth talks these days).
It's really the system where populists thrive.
I'm not sure there is a system without flaws, but maybe the double-round French one is to be preferred. With a sprinkle of German maybe.

snippet.textDisplay:
Sadly, I'm not at all surprised by the number of comments that claim that this video shows bias against the Conservatives, and is 'sour grapes' (or similar terms) because the Conservatives won the recent election.

It really is _nothing _ of the sort, it is a completely unbiased illustration of how a proper proportional representation system would greatly improve the representativeness of UK governments.

To those who are saying that the way people voted would have been different if we had a proportional representation system:
Yes, of course it would - but there is nothing wrong with TL/DR News using the recent election results to illustrate how the votes that were actually cast might have changed the composition of parliament (the only other thing that they could have done is to guess how people might have voted.
If we already had a system of proportional representation in place, it is quite possible that the smaller parties would have picked up an even higher proportion of seats than the illustrated example. Certainly the Brexit Party would have gained more seats, because they would have had good reason to keep candidates in all constituencies instead of standing down in seats the Conservatives already held.
In all likelihood, more of the people who don't vote would be encouraged to vote as well. I don't always vote in my constituency because it is a very safe seat held by a party (and currently an MP) who have consistently been completely against most of the things I believe are right for the country. No other candidate ever comes close to beating them - but with a proportional representation system my vote would actually count, even if I decided to vote for a 'small' party.

It's not quite true the current system doesn't reflect the population. Rather, there are different ways of measuring the population's positions, different ways emphasizing different things, and the current system is just one of a few ways to look at it.


Are there better ways? Perhaps. The different ways all have advantages and disadvantages, often emphasizing personal, subjective values.


For example, whether you value the member's link to their community higher or lower than the overall statistical breakdown will lead to different polling methods being better or worse for your preferences.

snippet.textDisplay:
Although Australia’s democracy has had a lot of flaws that have been highlighted in the past decade I really see how the UK would benefit from 3 aspects of our system.
1. Compulsory voting- so the result reflects all citizens, not just those that showed up

2- Preferential Voting - rankings your candidates from first to last so if two similar ideological parties get 30% of the vote a party with 35% doesn’t win despite 60% of the electorate not liking them

3- A senate of some sort, in Australia each election each state gets 6 seats. This means that minor parties that can’t get seats in the house of reps still get a say in the government. Unfortunately this has lead to many extremest right wing parties getting into power but it still allows more views to be shared.

If the UK implemented these, I believe the democracy would be a lot stronger.

It's a bit of a disingenuous counter-factual to use for any specific election though, because it ignores the fact that in a different electoral system, you'd end up with completely different parties and probably alter who ends up voting too. A lot of people don't vote at all in general elections simply because they don't like the main parties OR if they're in a safe blue/red seat and their party has no chance of winning, whereas they DID vote in the referendum because it was simply a single issue with no other allegiance being made.
You really can't do the counter-factual until you're living in that system and you've seen how it changes things in that particular country.
snippet.textOriginal:
It's a bit of a disingenuous counter-factual to use for any specific election though, because it ignores the fact that in a different electoral system, you'd end up with completely different parties and probably alter who ends up voting too. A lot of people don't vote at all in general elections simply because they don't like the main parties OR if they're in a safe blue/red seat and their party has no chance of winning, whereas they DID vote in the referendum because it was simply a single issue with no other allegiance being made.
You really can't do the counter-factual until you're living in that system and you've seen how it changes things in that particular country.

snippet.textDisplay: It's unfathomable that democracy could every function differently than proportionally in the first place; why it is FPTP is an entirely different conversation. That being said, to get Brexit finalised - in one way or the other - clear direction is required; while I don't think that even with a 'landslide' Conservative majority that guarantees a smooth Brexit resolution, it would be better than PR on such a divisive issue; PR or other 'fair' forms of democracy would be more beneficial in day-to-day politics. The trouble is, PR and similar voting systems are always favoured by the underdogs - when these become the top dog, suddenly it's unfavourable and the fearmongering about hung parliaments etc. always ensues. It would be nothing short of a miracle if British politics ever gets with modern demands on electoral reform, and gets out of FPTP.
snippet.textOriginal: It's unfathomable that democracy could every function differently than proportionally in the first place; why it is FPTP is an entirely different conversation. That being said, to get Brexit finalised - in one way or the other - clear direction is required; while I don't think that even with a 'landslide' Conservative majority that guarantees a smooth Brexit resolution, it would be better than PR on such a divisive issue; PR or other 'fair' forms of democracy would be more beneficial in day-to-day politics. The trouble is, PR and similar voting systems are always favoured by the underdogs - when these become the top dog, suddenly it's unfavourable and the fearmongering about hung parliaments etc. always ensues. snippet.textDisplay: My only criticism of the proportional system is that it’s biased towards people that live in the big cities. Considering that people living in London generally have different lifestyles and priorities compared to people living in the countryside, if a proportional system was instituted, people who don’t live in a largely populated city get less of a say and could be effectively silenced. The results will end up being primarily controlled by London, Manchester and Birmingham. In turn, political candidates will show far less interest in non-large-city folk and focus on pleasing only city demographics.

snippet.textDisplay:
In Mexico the people elect the representative they want both for the Senate and the lower house like a first past the post system. And there are extra seats given to each party according to its proportional representation, the so called plurinominal deputies, this reform was added in order to give the small parties some representation. And actually many people in Mexico aren't happy with this system, because nobody actually voted for those plurinominal MPs and in many cases the parties just put old politicians who nobody wants anymore.

There are of course many different proportional systems, but I don't think those are more fair. I prefer a system were you elect the person who will represent you, not vote for a party.
